section.title: Conservation of Energy of Moving Charges

introduction.p:
Electric force applied by a static electric field is a conservative force. Suppose a charge Q of mass m is subject to only electric force and is moving in a region where electric potential by all other charges is \phi. Then, we define its energy to be sum of its kinetic energy and electrical potential energy. Let's denote energy here by \mathcal{E} symbol to distinguish it from E which are using for electric field.
\mathcal{E} = \frac{1}{2} mv^2 + Q\phi.
Now, recall that potential varies from place to place, so, we might right \phi as a function of space \phi(x,y,z). Often, we use \vec r as a short hand for (x,y,z).
\mathcal{E} = \frac{1}{2} mv^2 + Q\phi(x,y,z) .
Therefore, if the particle moving under the influence of the electric field, goes from some point P_1(x_1, y_1, z_1), where it has speed v_1 to point P_2(x_2, y_2, z_2), where it has speed v_2, by conservation of energy we will have
\frac{1}{2} mv_1^2 + Q\phi(x_1,y_1,z_1) = \frac{1}{2} mv_2^2 + Q\phi(x_2,y_2,z_2).
If you have other forces, then, you will have to include potential energies corresponding to them as well, and any loss of energy or gain of energy by work by other forces. But, as long as you have only electrical force, Eq. will be applicable.

You must be careful when using Eq. . For instance, if you use this equation for an electron accelerating across a potential difference of more than 270\text{ kV}, you will get speed of electron to be more than the speed of light. This is not allowed by special relativity. You need a different analysis at high speeds.

exercise.title: Accelerating a Charged Particle Between two Conductors

statement.p: Two plates are maintained at a potential difference of 1,000\text{ V}. An electron is released from the negative plate at nearly zero speed. After a short time, the electron strikes the postive plate. What is the speed of the electron when it strikes the positive plate?

solution.p:
There is only electric force on the electron in the situation. Therefore, its energy is conserved. The two points we take are (1) near the negative plate and (2) near the positive plate. We have the following data:
\phi_1 = 0,\ \ \phi_2=1,000\text{ V},\ \ v_1 = 0,\ \ v_2=?.
Using Eq. , we get
0 + 0 = \frac{1}{2} m_e v_2^2 - e \times 1000.
Therefore,
v_2 \amp = \sqrt{ \dfrac{ 2000\, e}{ m_e} } = \sqrt{ \dfrac{ 2000\times 1.6\times 10^{-19}}{ 9.11\times 10^{-31}} } = 1.87\times 10^{7}\text{ m/s}.
